characters: 144B JOE RUBS HIS EYES AND LOOKS AGAIN
LITTLE SHELF ON MOUTH OF WOO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're in color now, but it's a grey world.  It's an ugly building about the size of a city block and a couple of stories high.  It's surrounded by hurricane fence topped with barbed wire.  Outside the fence is a muddy parking lot.  On the fence is a sign that reads: AMERICAN PANASCOPE CORP. a subsidiary of

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. 5/16/89

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The sign also has an abstract logo; a sort've German Expressionist's version of a lightning bolt.  Another sign reads:

dialogues.speaker: HOME OF THE RECTAL PROBE
dialogues.text: It's a grey winter's morning.  It's raining or snowing or it just has or it's about to.  There's a guard at a gate nodding workers inside the fence.  They trail listlessly past him and continue on their way to the building's entrance.  Most of them carry or are using grey or black umbrellas.  Since they are coming from the parking lot, and since the entrance to the building is still almost a city block away once inside the fence, this straggling line of workers stretches hundreds of yards.  Some of the workers wear hats. We see the line of workers FROM HIGH OVERHEAD The line is in the same shape as the lightning bolt logo. One of these workers is JOE BANKS.  Joe is in his early thirties.  He's wearing a beat-up black trench coat; under the trench coat he's got on a cheap and square jacket and tie.  This is a depressed man.  You can see where he could be cool, where he could have something on the ball.  But he's way too beaten down and depressed to be cool.  Joe steps in a puddle.  He pulls his shoe out of the water.  He notices the sole is coming loose from the shoe.  This depresses him further.  He walks on.  The sound of the WATER SQUISHING in his shoe can be heard. JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. 1/15/89

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe is shuffling down the main walk in the building.  On his left are doors leading to offices.  On his right is the factory, which has the feel of an airplane hangar. The factory is separated from the walk on which Joe progresses by a heavy wire fence twelve feet high.  Joe passes by a sign on this fence that says "Shipping." This area is filled with thousands of brown cardboard boxes; a shipping clerk among these boxes pulls a lever on a device; the device spews out several feet of wet brown tape.  Joe continues on.  He passes a sign on the fence that says "Canteen."  This area contains a row of vending machines and two long tables; a guy who looks like he's going to die is sitting at one of the tables eating pink Hostess snowballs; he eats them in a slow, dismal way, as if they were giant sleeping pills.  Joe continues on.  He passes a sign on the fence that says "Quality Control." This is the biggest area; it's filled with workers in shower caps and worn white jackets; they work a distance apart from each other, at long tables; they are inspecting terrifying medical instruments.  One of these workers, a middle-aged woman named Sally, attaches a catheter to an air pump.  The catheter inflates and finally explodes.  Sally seems satisfied.  Joe continues on, his shoe distantly SQUISHING.  He stops at one of the office doors on his left. The lettering on the door reads:

dialogues.speaker: ADVERTISING DEPARTMENT
dialogues.text: Joe opens the door and goes in.  The SONG ENDS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The place is lit with those totally draining, deadening fluorescent lights.  DEDE, a secretary in her late twenties, is sitting at her desk, typing.  She's pretty, maybe a little hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. 5/16/89

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She types like an automatic weapon.  Her makeup doesn't really work under these lights.  She nods briefly to Joe, and goes on with her typing.  Joe tries to hang up his hat, but it keeps falling off the hook.  He is endlessly patient.  It's the sound of the typewriter that makes him miss.  At last he succeeds.  Behind Dede, at a bigger desk, is MR. WATURI.  He's leaning back in an executive chair, talking on the phone.  He's middle-aged, olive skinned, in a dark suit that shows up his significant dandruff.  His teeth are yellow as rancid butter.  And there's enough grease shining on his forehead to coat a skillet.  He's talking into the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, Harry, but can he do the job?  I know he can get the job, but can he do the job? I'm not arguing that with you. I'm not arguing that with you. I'm not arguing that with you Mr. Waturi waves absently at Joe and goes on talking into the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who told you that?  No.  I told you that.  Me.  What? Maybe. Maybe.  Maybe. Joe hangs up his coat on the coat rack and goes to the coffee set-up at the rear of the office.  He snaps a disposable plastic coffee cup into a permanent plastic holder.  He puts a spoonful of instant coffee in the cup. Then a spoonful of powdered creamer.  Then two spoonfuls of sugar.  He takes a plastic stirrer and stirs the powders.  He pours in the hot water and stirs.  Little clumps of undissolved stuff rise to the top.  Joe tries to break them up with the stirrer and partially succeeds. He feels the glands in his throat.  Maybe they're a little swollen.  He rubs his eyes.  They're burning a little.  He takes his coffee and walks past Mr. Waturi and into his own office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The same fluorescent lighting.  There's a small wooden desk which has on it an old electric typewriter and an out-of-place lamp; it's a lamp Joe brought from home. The rest of the office is almost entirely taken up with grey industrial shelving.  On these shelves are brochures depicting various medical instruments.  Samples of each brochure are taped to the appropriate shelf.  Behind Joe's desk is a pipe that runs floor-to-ceiling and is painted fire-engine red.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: In the center of this pipe is a big wheel valve.  Hanging from this valve is a printed metal sign. The sign reads:  THE MAIN DRAIN.  Another sign reads: Do Not Touch.  Joe turns on the lamp, which casts a small ring of golden light, and sits down with his coffee.  He takes off his shoe and examines it.  He tries to huddle close to the lamp, like a cold creature trying to get warm.  Dede comes in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, Dede.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Joe.  What's with the shoe?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm losing my sole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. How you doin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a little tired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. (she hands him some labels)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here.  Each one gets sent five catalogs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I only got twelve catalogs left altogether.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. She leaves.  Joe puts his shoe back on.  Mr. Waturi comes in.  Joe cowers.  He's threatened by Mr. Waturi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How you doin', Joe?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm not feeling very good, Mr. Waturi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. 5/16/89

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Mr. Waturi chuckles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. 1/15/89

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what else is new? You never feel good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Well. That's the problem. Anyway, I got the doctor's appointment today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another doctor's appointment?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, Joe.  What's this Dede tells me about the catalogs?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've only got twelve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How'd you let us get down to twelve?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three weeks ago.  Then two weeks ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you tell me last week?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.  I thought you knew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not good enough, Joe!  Not nearly good enough!  I put you in charge of the entire advertising library...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean, this room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gave you carte blanche how to deal with the materials in here...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You put the orders into the printer, Mr. Waturi, not me. That's how you wanted it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not competent to put the orders into the printer! That's a very technical...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you were going to explain it to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was going to do better than that.  I was going to make you assistant manager.  I want to make you assistant manager. But you, you're not flexible! You're inflexible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't feel inflexible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're inflexible.  Totally. And this doctor appointment! You're always going to the doctor!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't feel good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what!  Do you think I feel good?  Nobody feels good. After childhood, it's a fact of life.  I feel rotten.  So what?  I don't let it bother me.  I don't let it interfere with my job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want from me, Mr. Waturi?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're like a child.  What's this lamp for?  Isn't there enough light in here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These fluorescent lights affect me.  They make me feel blotchy, puffy.  I thought this light would...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get rid of the light.  This isn't your bedroom, this is an office. Maybe if you start treating this like a job instead of some kind of welfare hospital, you'll shape up. And I want those catalogs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then please order them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watch yourself, Joe.  Think about what I've said.  You've gotta get yourself into a flexible frame or you're no place. He starts to leave, but stops and looks back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take that light off your desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take it off now. Joe unplugs the light and takes it off his desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. Waturi leaves.  Joe sits at his desk, shrinking in the fluorescent light.  He sips his coffee. The PHONE RINGS and he answers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Advertising library.  Fifty? I'm sorry, we don't have that many in stock.  I don't know why.  The catalog is a thing... I don't know.  It's here and it's gone.  I can't explain.  It's a mystery. He hangs up the phone.  Dede has quietly come in.  She's looking at Joe.  She speaks to him in a low voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you let Waturi talk to you like that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't... feel very good. She looks at him.  She's frustrated with this guy.  This is somebody who she could go for, but he's just lying there like a dog waiting to be kicked.  He looks at her. If he had the strength, if he were feeling a little better, he'd make a play for this woman.  But he's helpless.  He just doesn't feel very good.  Absently, he feels the glands in his throat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. She stares at him.  She's angry, frustrated.  She turns and walks out. Joe's eyes are shining with tears that will not fall.  He is powerless to help himself.  He mutters to himself, fierce and impotent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. He presses the heels of his hands into his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We discover Joe with the heels of his hands pressed into his eyes.  This room is fluorescently lit, too, and perhaps at first we don't realize we have gone somewhere else.  A nurse's voice is heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Banks?  Mr. Banks? Joe, startled, takes his hands from his eyes. The CAMERA PULLS BACK and we see we're in a doctor's waiting room. And now we see the NURSE.  She is a very conservative, W.A.S.P. Nurse .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doctor Ellison will see you now. JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. 5/16/89

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lighting in the doctor's office is the first warm, relaxing light we've seen.  It comes from lamps and a little frosted window.  The office itself is full of old wood and books.  DR. ELLISON sits in a comfortable chair, at an old desk.  He is the last word in doctors.  He's a large, respectable, distinguished, greyed-haired M.D. He's a specialist.  You get the feeling he may be a genius.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How are you feeling, Mr. Banks?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pretty much the same.  I feel puffy, blotchy.  I never seem to have very much energy.  I get these little sore throats. I just don't feel good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And how long have you felt this way?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well.  Pretty much since I left the Fire Department.  On and off. But since then. 'Bout eight years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you do in the Fire Department?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, ah, you know, I put out fires.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was it dangerous?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  Ahm, pretty rough stuff. But I came out of it okay.  The hard part was not feeling good all the time.  I started not feeling good all the time.  So I hadda quit. Ellison nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  I've gotten the results of your tests.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. 6/2/89

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got cancer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This new venereal...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there something wrong with my blood or urine or...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, they're fine.  But there is something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have a brain cloud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A brain cloud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a black fog of tissue running right down the center of your brain.  It's very rare.  It will spread at a regular rate. It's very destructive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And it's incurable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Six months.  You can pretty much count on it being about that. It's not painful.  Your brain will simply fail. Followed abruptly by your body.  You can depend on at least four and half or five months of perfect health.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. 6/2/89

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But what are you talking about, Doctor?  I don't feel good right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the ironic part, really. Mr. Banks, you're a hypochondriac. There's nothing wrong with you that has anything to do with your symptoms.  My guess is your experiences in the Fire Department were extremely traumatic.  You experienced the imminent possibility of death.  Several times? (as Joe nods numbly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You survived.  But the cumulative anxiety of those brushes with death left you habitually fearful. About your physical person.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not sick?  Except for this terminal disease?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which has no symptoms.  That's right.  It was only because of your insistence on having so many tests that we happened to discover the problem. Joe laughs, a little maniacally, then stops abruptly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What am I going to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, if you have any savings you might think about taking a trip, a vacation?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't have any savings.  A few hundred bucks.  I've spent everything on doctors.

dialogues.speaker: ELLISON
dialogues.text: Yes.  Perhaps you'll want a second opinion?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A brain cloud.  I knew it. Well, I didn't know it, but I knew it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. 5/16/89

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What am I going to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have some time left, Mr. Banks. You have some life left. My advice to you is: Live it well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got to go.  I'm on my lunch hour which is over. Joe gets up and Ellison follows suit, putting out his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry for what I had to tell you. I wish the news had been better. Joe doesn't take his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah . Joe leaves. Ellison starts to sit down. Joe comes back in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry I didn't shake your hand. Joe takes the doctor's hand and shakes it.  Then he drops it and exits abruptly.  Ellison sits there a moment, not moving.  Then he opens a drawer in his desk and takes out a flask.  He pours himself a drink and begins to drink it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the building Ellison's office is in.  Joe's car is parked out front.  Joe comes slowly out.  It's still overcast, but lighter and dryer than it was earlier. As Joe walks down the steps, an elderly woman approaches with her dog, Molly, a mutt.  Joe sees the dog and stops, fixed on it.  He pats the dog on the head.  The elderly woman thinks this is nice. Then Joe embraces the dog, and kneeling down, hugs it intensely.  The elderly woman is alarmed and pulls the dog away.  Joe looks after them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. 5/16/89

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Then he gets in his car, which is beat-up and beige. Drives off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe drives INTO FRAME.  He gets out and we FOLLOW him as he approaches the GUARD at the gate.  The Guard nods him in.  He starts to walk past.  Then he goes back to the Guard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fred.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fred. He thinks that over and then goes on his way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe standing outside the door marked Advertising Dept. He is thoughtful.  He goes in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe comes in.  Dede is typing away.  Mr. Waturi is on the phone.  Joe hangs up his coat.  He misses with the hat again because of Dede's typing.  He leans over and switches the typewriter off.  Then he picks up his hat, dusts it off and throws it in the garbage can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  No.  You were wrong.  He was wrong.  Who said that?  I didn't say that.  If I had said that, I would've been wrong.  I would've been wrong, Harry, isn't that right? Mr. Waturi's attention is split between his call and Joe, who is walking around the office like a tourist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, let me call you back, I've got something here, okay? And don't tell him anything till we finish our conversation, okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. 6/2/89

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Mr. Waturi hangs up the phone.  Joe is looking at the coffee set-up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were at lunch three hours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About that. Joe wanders away, into his office.  Waturi looks after.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe is staring at the big wheel valve sporting the sign that says Main Drain.  Mr. Waturi comes in as Joe moves forward and, with great effort, rotates the wheel to its opposite extreme.  This scares Waturi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe, what are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm opening, or closing, the main drain. Nothing happens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You shouldn't be touching that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing happened.  Do you know how long I've been wondering what would happen if I did that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brain cloud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never mind.  Listen, Mr. Waturi. Frank.  I quit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. 5/16/89

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Joe starts to take some stuff out of his desk.  He looks at his lamp, gets the cord, plugs it in, and turns it on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean, today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's great.  Well, don't come looking for a reference.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, I won't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You blew this job. Joe takes in the little room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been here for four and a half years.  The work I did I probably could've done in five, six months. That leaves four years leftover. He's been filling up a shopping bag with stuff from his desk:  three books (Romeo and Juliet, Robinson Crusoe and The Odyssey), an old ukulele and his lamp.  Now he's finished.  He walks out of the room without even looking at Waturi.  Waturi goes after him as he exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe is walking towards the front door.  Waturi follows him in.  Joe stops at Dede's desk. She's typing.  He looks at her.  She stops typing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four years.  If I had them now. Like gold in my hand. Here.  This is for you. (gives Dede the lamp)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Bye-bye, Dede.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, if you're leaving, leave. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. 6/2/89

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll get your check.  And, I promise you, you'll be easy to replace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should say something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This life.  Life?  What a joke. This situation   This room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe, maybe you should just...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look terrible, Mr. Waturi. You look like a bag of shit stuffed inna cheap suit.  Not that anyone would look good under these zombie lights.  I can feel them sucking the juice outta my eyeballs. Three hundred bucks a week, that's the news.  For three hundred bucks a week I've lived in this sink. This used rubber.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watch it, mister!  There's a woman here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you think I know that, Frank? Don't you think I'm aware there's a woman here?  I can taste her on my tongue.  I can smell her.  When I'm twenty feet away, I can hear the fabric of her dress when she moves in her chair.  Not that I've done anything about it.  I've gone all day, every day, not doing, not saying, not taking the chance for three hundred bucks a week, and Frank the coffee stinks it's like arsenic, the lights give me a headache if the lights don't give you a headache you must be dead, let's arrange the funeral.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. 6/2/89

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You better get outta here right now!  I'm telling you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're telling me nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm telling you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And why, I ask myself, why have I put up with you?  I can't imagine but I know. Fear.  Yellow freakin' fear. I've been too chicken shit afraid to live my life so I sold it to you for three hundred freakin' dollars a week! You're lucky I don't kill you! You're lucky I don't rip your freakin' throat out! But I'm not going to and maybe you're not so lucky at that. 'Cause I'm gonna leave you here, Mister Wa-a-Waturi, and what could be worse than that? Joe opens the door and leaves.  Mr. Waturi and Dede are frozen.  The door reopens and Joe comes halfway back in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dede?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How 'bout dinner tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, uh, okay. Joe smiles for the first time since we've met him, and closes the door again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow.  What a change.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who does he think he is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe and Dede are sitting at a table, steaming plates of food before them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. 1/15/89

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: They are drinking red wine.  Joe is caught up in a big idea.  Dede is mesmerized.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, who am I?  That's the real question, isn't it?  Who am I? Who are you?  What other questions are there?  What other questions are there, really?  If you want to understand the universe, embrace the universe, the door to the universe is you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You.  Me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are really intense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Am I?  I guess I am.  I was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, a long time ago.  In the beginning.  I was full of piss and vinegar.  Nothing got me down.  I wanted to know!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wanted to know what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything!  But then, I had some experiences... I was talking to this guy today, he says I got scared.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scared of what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you ever been scared?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess so.  Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What scared you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lot of things.  At the moment, you scare me a little bit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Across the room, at another table, three guys with guitars, in traditional Spanish costumes, sing a happy Castilian song.  Dede and Joe turn and take in the singers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why would I scare you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.  There's something going on with you. This morning you were like a lump and now you're... How do you feel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See?  You never feel great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I never do. He laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's funny?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do feel great.  And that is very funny!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm right here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish I was where you are, Joe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. 5/16/89

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you don't.  Did I ever tell you that the first time I saw you, I felt I'd seen you before? She shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. 4/14/89

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Joe gets up, goes over to the three guys with guitars, slips them a fin, confers briefly, and returns to the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I bribed them to sing a song that would drive us insane and make our hearts swell and burst. Whereupon the three guys with guitars arrive at the table and launch into an extremely passionate Castilian love song.  The song makes conversation impossible.  Joe pours Dede some more red wine.  They toast, looking into each other's eyes.  The scene ends, but the SONG CONTINUES through the following.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Against a slightly tilting lamp post leans a sailor in uniform.  Joe and Dede emerge from the restaurant and get in his beat-up car.  The car pulls away.  The SONG CONTINUES through the following.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ferry pulls away from the shore.  Joe and Dede go to the railing and look back at Manhattan, all lit up, receding.  They kiss and look again.  The song continues through next.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe's car pulls to a stop in front of it, and he and Dede get out.  There are some steps.  He kisses her and carries her up the steps.  Then he puts her down to open the door.  The SONG ENDS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe throws open the door with one hand.  He's got Dede on his arm.  They kiss passionately.  Joe reluctantly ends the kiss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. 1/15/89

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened to you that you're ... so alive?  I can see it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doctor told me I've got this thing wrong with my brain.  It's not catching. But I've just got five or six months to live.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna die.  And it's made me. very appreciative of my life. Dede shrinks from him, clutching her coat, suddenly cold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've gotta go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please don't. He reaches for her.  She steps back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've gotta go home.  You may've quit, but I got the job in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dede, I really want you to stay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're gonna die?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but so what?  Stay! Just tonight.  Tomorrow'll take care of itself. She hesitates on the brink of staying, lifts her hands to say yes, but her courage fails her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't handle it, Joe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. 5/16/89

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She drops her hands, grabs the doorknob, and opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry. She quickly goes, slamming the door after her.  Joe looks after her blankly.  Then he takes off his coat, tie and jacket, and throws them on the floor.  He walks off down the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe is making some real coffee.  He's changed into bathrobe.  He's got a little lamp on, not the overhead light.  He opens the refrigerator and takes out a loaf of white bread.  He puts a couple of slices in the toaster. Then he looks at his little tin dining table and at window.  The window is so dirty it's opaque.  You'd like to open it to see out.  He pulls the table over to window.  Then he pulls a chair over to face the window. The window looks out on a long little street.  At the end of the street is a brightness, where the sun will be.  He brings his coffee to the table, and a napkin, and a a spoon. He hears the TOAST POP.  He gets it, puts it on a plate, butters it, and brings it to the table.  He sits down. He takes a sip of coffee and a bite of toast.  He 1ooks out the window.  The sun is just starting to come up. He looks at the coffee, at the little whiff of steam rising from the cracked cup.  The crack's in the shape of ACHI logo.  He looks at the toast with one bite missing and the butter melting into the golden bread.  He 1ooks at the sun's splendid red rim.  These things are so beautiful.  His eyes well up.  He takes another bite of the toast and another sip of the coffee and looks at the rising sun.  It's so great that he's here to experience these things, and so sad that he's leaving.  He goes back to the refrigerator and takes out the loaf of bread. He puts a couple of more slices in the toaster and the almost full loaf of bread next to the almost full pot of coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The loaf of bread is almost gone and the pot of coffee is empty.  Now we PULL BACK and see Joe sitting by the window with his feet up, some crusts of toast lying on the plate next to him.  The sun has risen a goodly bit, and can no longer be seen by us.  But Joe is dappled with sunlight.  He is no longer in the thrall of a big emotion, but he is extremely deep in the thought.  The DOORBELL RINGS.  Joe doesn't move.  It RINGS AGAIN.  Did he hear the doorbell?  It RINGS AGAIN.  He is now satisfied the doorbell is ringing.  He gets up and out into the foyer. JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. 5/16/89

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The DOORBELL starts to RING AGAIN as Joe opens the door. In the hallway is a powerful, glittering-eyed old man of seventy, MR. GRAYNAMORE.  He's wearing a long, black cashmere overcoat, a dramatic but not silly black fedora, and cowboy boots.  He carries a vacuum-sealed can of Planter's Peanuts in his pocket.  He's got a cane with a duck's head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe Banks?  Mr. Joe Banks?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have I come at a bad time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  No.  I don't know how to answer that question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I come in? Can we talk? Joe throwing the door open.  He's in his bathrobe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not dressed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doesn't bother me if it doesn't bother you. Graynamore strides past Joe into Joe's living room.  Joe looks after, in a bit of a daze.  Then he follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's modest, to say the least.  It's messy and cheaply furnished.  An enormous crack runs up the wall and across the ceiling.  Graynamore takes the room in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not a nice place you have here, Joe.  Mind if I call you Joe?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Graynamore smacks a hole in the wall with his cane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. 5/16/89 21        CONTINUED:  (Al)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dingy, shabby, dinky, not much. He rips off his coat with gusto and tosses it away.  He sings a little of "Someone's in the Kitchen With Dinah."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. 4/14/89

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He's a rich man, from out West, and that's what his clothes look like.  He seems to be enjoying himself very much.  He sticks out his hand to Joe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see it as a sign of tremendous sophistication that you haven't demanded my name or asked me what I'm doing here.  My name is Samuel Harvey Graynamore. They shake hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe Banks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. (stares into Joe's face)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm trying to see the hero in there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You dragged two kids down a six-story burning staircase. That was brave.  But then you went back up for the third. That was heroic.  Com'on, you're a hero.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was a long time ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, it was. Graynamore opens the nuts and dumps them on the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you know my name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know all about you.  As much as I could learn in twenty- four hours, anyway.  Peanuts?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. 4/14/89

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quit your job, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, sounded like a dumb job. No family?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. 6/2/89

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good for you.  Families are a pain in the neck. What do you know about superconductors ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me neither.  But I own a huge company that dominates the world market for superconductors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  Sit down. Graynamore sits down, suddenly grounded and serious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got a call from Dr. Ellison. You were at his office yesterday? Joe nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He told me your news.  I hope you won't be angry with him. He thought you and I might be able to help each other.  Got any whiskey? Joe shakes his head.  Graynamore produces a pipe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to hire you, Joe Banks. I want you... Graynamore strikes an enormous match and lights up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: to jump into a volcano. Joe jumps up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do have some whiskey. Joe pulls a bottle of cheap scotch out of a cabinet, along with two glasses.  He pours them both a drink and sits down.  Graynamore downs his whiskey which makes his eyes glitter all the more.  He leans forward and speaks with great intensity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. 6/2/89

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's an island in the South Pacific called Waponi Woo. The name means 'The Little Island With the Big Volcano.' The Waponis are a cheerful people who live a simple existence fishing in the lagoon and picking fruit.  They have one fear.  That's a big volcano, they call it The Big Woo. They believe an angry fire god in the volcano will sink the island unless, once every hundred years, he is appeased. It's been ninety-nine years, eleven months, and eleven days since the fire god got his propers and the Waponis are scared.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's the god appeased?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of his own free will, a man's got to jump into the volcano. Now as you might imagine, none of the Waponis are anxious to volunteer for the honor of jumping into the Big Woo.  And the problem is that whoever does it gotta do it of his own free will so what do you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you do? Graynamore gets up and starts to move around the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You do some tradin'.  There's a mineral on that island, Mr. Banks. It's called bubureau. I don't know anywhere else on the planet where you can find more than a gram of this stuff, and believe me I've looked.  Because without bubureau I can't make my superconductors.  I've tried to get the mineral rights from the Waponis, but I don't seem to have anything they want. But they do want a hero, Mr. Banks.  And they'll give me the mineral rights if I find them one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why would I jump into a volcano?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. 6/2/89

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Graynamore moves behind Joe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From your exploits in the Fire Department, I think you've got the courage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does it take more guts to twice traverse a staircase in flames, or to make a onetime leap into the mouth of a smoking volcano? Damned if I know, kimosabe.  All I know is when you're making those kind of calls, you're up in the high country. From your doctor, you know you're on your way out anyway.  You haven't got any money.  I checked. (grabs Joe by the shoulders)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you want to wait it out here, in this apartment?  That sounds kind a grim to me. It's not how I'd wanna go, I'll tell you that. Graynamore lets go of his shoulders.  He takes out his wallet and lays out four credit cards on the stereo console:  Diner's Club, Gold Visa, Gold Master, and Gold American Express.  The cards have Joseph Banks printed on them.  Joe looks at the cards.  We hear Graynamore's voice as we look at the cards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These are yours if you take the job.  It'd be twenty days from today before you'd have to actually jump in the Big Woo.  You could shop today, get yourself some clothes, you know, for an adventure.  Then tomorrow a plane to L.A. first class, naturally. You'll be met.  Stay in the best hotel. Then the next day, you board a yacht.  My competitors sometimes watch the airports. The yacht's a real beauty. (produces wallet photo of the yacht)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It belongs to me.  Gourmet chef. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ### - continued & page number

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: missing

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sail to the South Pacific. Then, fifteen days. The Waponis come out to meet you, a total red carpet situation, you're a national hero. You're Charles Lindbergh. It's wine, women and song in the sweetest little paradise you ever saw. Then you jump in the volcano. Live like a king, die like a man, that's what I say. What do you say? (picks up the credit cards and looks ###ks at Graynamore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright. I'll do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's my card and your plane ticket. American, noon out of Kennedy tomorrow. (picks up his coat and hat and heads for door)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Graynamore?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if I use the cards and take the plane and go on the yacht and party on the island and then I change  my mind and I don't jump in the volcano?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why then I'd kill you in a very slow and painful way.  But you'll jump. (laughs in a warm and wonderful way, goes to door, opens it, and leaves.) Joe stands there, ###er him for a moment, and then pulls out the ###s.  He flips through, finds what he wants, and ### number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, I'd like to rent a limousine JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. 5/16/89

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you?  Yes, I do. American Express.  The Gold Card.  Can I have a white limousine? Joe smiles, looking at the card in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car has just emerged from Staten Island Ferry traffic.  We see the friendly face on the front grill of the limousine.  It is a slightly overcast day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe is sitting in the back, idly plucking his ukulele, looking out the windows, stretching his legs. Driver is a middle-aged black man; his name is MARSHALL.  He's wearing a jacket and tie and sunglasses. He seems reserved and efficient

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So where would you like to go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - -Rev. 3/23/89

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where would you like to go, sir? Joe thinks for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought I might like to do some shopping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.  Where would you like to go shopping?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Marshall is disgruntled, but hides it behind his reserve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where would you go shopping?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For what?  What do you need?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clothes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of clothes?  What is your taste?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't exactly know. Marshall pulls the car over and stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why'd you stop?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just hired to drive the car, mister.  I'm not here to tell you who you are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't ask you to tell me who I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. 5/16/89

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were hinting around about clothes.  It happens that clothes are very important to me, Mister..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Banks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Banks.  Clothes make the man. I believe that.  You say to me you wanna go shopping, you wanna buy clothes, but you don't know what kind.  You leave that hanging in the air, like I'm going to fill in the blank, that to me is like asking me who you are, and I don't know who you are, I don't wanna know.  It's taken me my whole life to find out who I am and I'm tired now, you hear what I'm say in'? What's your name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name's Marshall, how you do? They shake hands quite seriously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute.  I'm coming back. Marshall gets out of the driver's seat, goes back and gets in next to Joe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now what's your situation? Explain your situation to me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going away on a long trip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got the opportunity to buy some clothes today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. 5/16/89

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Money's no object.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.  Where you going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well.  I'm going out tonight in the city.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice places?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope so.  Then tomorrow I'm flying to L.A.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First class?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I'm getting on a yacht and sailing to the South Pacific. MARSHALL Hawaii?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  A really unknown little island.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No tourists?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I'll be on the island for a couple of weeks, then that's it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what do you got in the way of clothes now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. 6/7/89

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I've got the kind of clothes I'm wearin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you've got no clothes. We'll start with basics. We'll start with underwear. We'll start with Dunhill. Marshall gets out of the car and heads back for the driver's seat. He thinks.  Marshall puts the car in gear and pulls away from the curb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The white limo pulls up. Two dog bars bracket the entrance to Dunhill with two big matching dogs, probably great Danes, drinking at each of the dog bars.  The dogs are held on leashes by a man in a business suit and a woman in a pretty coat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe's getting ready to get out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So just socks and underwear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conservative underwear is the only way to go.  White cotton broadcloth boxers.  Silk shorts make you feel like a whore, so none of that.  But with the tee shirts, Egyptian cotton, all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright. Joe gets out of the car and goes in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A conservative UNDERGARMENT SALESMAN is helping Joe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many pairs of boxer shorts would you like, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. 6/7/89

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many does a man need? The Salesman pauses, thinks and replies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SALESMAN Eight pairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marshall's leaning against the limo, reading a copy of The Scientific American. A WOMAN appears dressed as the Statue of Liberty.  She looks at Marshall.  He returns the glance.  She has a tin can in her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about a dollar for the way I look?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shoot.  How 'bout a dollar for the way I look? He gives her a dollar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. She exits.  Joe comes out of the store with a shopping bag.  Marshall opens the door for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They've got a changing room. I'm wearing the underwear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew that. I could see it on your face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What else you need?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, well, some kind of overcoat. I don't know, maybe like a English trench coat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. 6/7/89

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: English trench coat?  That's foul weather wear, man. You're goin' west!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What would you get?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a sexual man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not that I mean to be crude, but I'm trying to express something.  Armani.  That's what you want.  And how 'bout a haircut?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong with my hair?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't express it.  It looks like freedom without choice. It looks wrong. While he's talking, he has picked up the car phone and punched some numbers.  He speaks into the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salon Salon, please. He breaks the connection and dials again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, gimme Cassie Cimorelli, please. Hello, Cassie?  It's Marshall, how you?  Good. Listen, I got somebody who needs you today, can you help me out?  2:30?  Great, good, thanks. He hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We gotta get moving. He puts the car in gear and pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The white limo pulls up. JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. 5/16/89

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what do I ask for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is too complicated.  I gotta come in with you.  If I getta ticket it can't be helped.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe and Marshall get out and go in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe is standing on a fitting stool in a beautiful suit. He's being ministered to by an ITALIAN TAILOR, as Marshall supervises.  Marshall murmurs to the Tailor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I still think the full break over the shoe is the way to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No more than half this year, I swear to you. (to Joe)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can take it off now, sir. Points the way to Joe and walks off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Joe, how about a tux?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something'll come up.  There's nothing a man looks better in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll get one if you get one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't be buying no Armani tux. I'm a working man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're getting paid to drive the car.  Nobody's paying you to give me all this advice. Let me buy you the tux and we'll call it even.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. 6/7/89

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Marshall thinks it over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marshall is standing on the fitting stool in an Armani tuxedo. The Tailor is doing his cuffs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gimme the full break over the shoe, Pietro.  It's my preference.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever's your pleasure, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: emerge.  Marshall opens the door to the limo for Joe and urges him to speed it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, kid!  We're on a roll! (as he walks around to the driver's side)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't even get a ticket. Marshall gets in, starts it up, and pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two Tiki heads bracket either side of the entrance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe is trying on a safari jacket.  Two salesmen stand by. Joe nods.  Now one of the salesmen puts a particularly dashing safari hat on Joe.  He looks in a mirror.  He really, really likes it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a large, bustling beauty center in midtown.  There must be fifteen hairdressers spread out over a spacious, well-windowed area.  It's a festive place with glossy magazines and coffee and water running and blow dryers going.  Happy BRAZILIAN MUSIC is playing on the sound system.  Now we zero in on Cassie's corner.  CASSIE is in her thirties, with a short fetching up-to-the-minute haircut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. 6/7/89

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She's also got a terrific personality; she's the salt of the earth.  And she's cutting Joe's hair.  Marshall sits on a nearby chair.  He's reading B, a trendy magazine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How you making me look?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm undoing this cut from before. This is some piece of geography. Where'd you get this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In one of those subway barber shops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It has that reality.  Grim. You're a very handsome guy, I'm just gonna bring that out. Marshall, which one is that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the in and out issue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the best!  What's in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carrie Fisher, Barcelona, African-Americans, happy endings, The New York Dally News, tomato salads, God, garlic, wristwatches you have to wind up, and true love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you say Carrie Fisher?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't like Carrie Fisher?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love Carrie Fisher!  I can't believe it!  So intelligent! So dry!  That's a totally great list. What's out?  Read it slow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kafka, C.D.'s.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's true.  I've had it with Kafka.  Those little eyes...so full of misery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. 6/7/89

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stand-up comedy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stand-up comedy makes me nervous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All restaurants that haven't been in existence for at least thirty years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paloma Picasso.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I don't agree with that. I love Paloma Picasso.  Those lips! So red, so big!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: New money and old money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All camp, all trash, all trivia...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh com'on, take a risk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And The New York Times.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finally somebody said it! What rag! Cassie finishes cutting Joe's hair.  It's a great cut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very gratifying.  Thank you, Marshall.  Well, here you are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I look good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're coming into focus, kid! I can see you now. Marshall nods approval.  Cassie and Joe exchange a smile. JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. 6/7/89

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The limo pulls up.  Joe goes in. Marshall stays in the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE ON the indoor golfing practice green.  Joe putts a golf ball into the hole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. Joe walks OUT OF FRAME. CLOSEUP PAN ACROSS the glass counter top of a Swiss army knife, a world band travel radio, shaving kit, lantern and a violin case that doubles as a bar; until we COME TO a large light colored umbrella which is pointed AT us.  The umbrella closes, revealing Joe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take this, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will that be all? Joe walks away.

dialogues.speaker: 40A PICTURE CUT-OUT
dialogues.text: of a woman demonstrating the walk on water shoes.  Joe approaches.  The SALESWOMAN appears as well.  Joe is really looking at the shoes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does that interest your

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean you can walk on water?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a little help.  Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take a pair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. 6/7/89

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright.  Very good, sir. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank YOU.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two uniformed attendants from Armani are handing the last of the boxes to Joe, who's now sitting in front with Marshall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. 4/14/89

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The back of the car is completely loaded with stuff.  The attendants head back to the entrance where they stand at parade rest on either side of the door.  Joe calls after.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks! Marshall pulls away from the curb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what you need?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What else could I need?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How you gonna carry this stuff? You need luggage!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't think of that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's as quiet as a church.  A few pieces of extremely high quality leather luggage are on display.  The SALESMAN, a small neat man in a quiet suit, is the store's representative.  He's talking with Joe.  He's a very serious, understated man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you thought much about luggage, Mr. Banks?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I never really have.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the central preoccupation of my life.  You travel the world, you're away from home, perhaps away from your family, all you have to depend on is yourself and your luggage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess that's true.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you traveling light or heavy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heavy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. 5/16/89

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flying?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flying.  And by ship.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An ocean voyage?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah.  Yes.  So.  A real journey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then I'll be staying on this island, I don't even really know if I'll be living in a hut or what.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SALESMAN Very exciting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As a luggage problem.  I believe I have just the thing. The Luggage Salesman rolls out an absolutely gorgeous steamer trunk of dark, wine-colored leather and brass fittings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow. The Luggage Salesman opens it. It has hangers, drawers, a mirror, the works.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is our premier steamer trunk.  All handmade, only the finest materials.  It's even water-tight, tight as a drum. If I had the need and the wherewithal, Mr. Banks, this would be my trunk of choice. I could face the world with a trunk like this by my side. Joe is moved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. 6/2/89

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take four of them. This is the classiest thing the Luggage Salesman's ever heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May you live to be a thousand years old, sir. Not normally a demonstrative man, he slowly raises hand, offering it to Joe.  Joe takes it and they shake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marshall and Joe have just finished securing the four trunks to the top of the white limo.  They get in the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marshall starts it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm through shopping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fair enough.  Where to? Back to Staten Island?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I guess so.  No.  A really good hotel.  The Plaza?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Plaza's nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where would you go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (lighting up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Pierre!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seven bellboys and girls are unloading the white limo and carrying its contents into the hotel.  They wear classic bellboy uniforms and caps.  Marshall and Joe are watching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. 5/16/89

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marshall?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wonder if you'd want to have dinner with me tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't do it.  I got my wife and kids at the end of the day, you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. The HEAD BELLMAN informs Joe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything's at check-in when you're ready, sir. The Bellman departs within.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, ain't you got nobody?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  But there are certain times in your life when I guess you're not supposed to have anybody, you know?  There are certain doors you have to go through alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're gonna be Alright. Joe shrugs.  He and Marshall shake hands.  They look at each other.  We see Marshall get in the limo and pull away.  We see Joe look after him, then turn and go into the hotel.

dialogues.speaker: MUSIC
dialogues.text: A instrumental jazz version of "Do You Know The Way To San Jose" plays through the following scenes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe has one of his trunks open.  He's hanging his tuxedo up in it.  He's been taking stuff out of boxes and packing it into the trunks.  He opens another box and takes out his new suit.  The MUSIC CONTINUES through the next. JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. 6/2/89

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is an incredibly beautiful, quiet restaurant.  Joe's discovered, sitting alone at a table. The Pierre waiter is just walking away.  Joe's sipping a glass of wine, his entree before him.  The MUSIC CONTINUES through next.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walking along.  As he approaches The Plaza, two cabs pull up and eight theatregoers from out of town disembark. They are all middle-aged, wearing their best clothes, having a good time.  They cross in front of Joe on their way into the hotel.  He watches them go by and disappear. It makes him smile and it makes him feel alone.  He goes on.  The MUSIC CONTINUES through next.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe walks by and stops, struck by the contents of the win dow.  It's a female dummy, dressed as Patricia will be on the yacht.  Behind the dummy is a photo mural of the yacht.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've arrived at the place where the music is coming from.  Joe sits at a little table listening to a good jazz quartet.  They are a pasty-faced English quartet. Everyone in the club is black except Joe, the bartender and the band, which is playing "Do You Know The Way to San Jose."  Everyone is drinking martinis.  They form a straight line down the bar each with a giant green olive in it.  Joe finishes a martini and waves for the check. The MUSIC CONTINUES through the next.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe, weaving ever so slightly, walks up the street and approaches the hotel.  The MUSIC CONCLUDES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lights are out.  Joe's in bed, staring at the ceiling.  We look DOWN on him.  It's very, very silent. Finally, he closes his eyes and turns his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. 5/16/89

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the flight to L.A.  Joe is sitting on the aisle.  Next to him is a grey-haired, wholesome priest named FATHER CONROY.  The clergyman is most way through a drink, wrapped up in his own thoughts.  Joe is deeply aware that he's sitting next to a priest; he's uneasy, shifting in his chair.  The STEWARDESS notices Joe and approaches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I get you anything, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. 1/15/89

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, thank you.  No, I changed my mind.  Some club soda, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright. Father Conroy catches her eye and slightly raises his almost empty drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I'll have one more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright. The Stewardess heads off, down the aisle.  Joe catches the priest's eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you ever been to California before?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, many times.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've never been anywhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was a chaplain there, years ago.  For the Marines.  Camp Pendleton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't believe in God

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did when I was a kid, but I lost my faith in high school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then, when I was in danger - I was a fireman - in the middle of the fire, I never like turned around and fell to my knees and started praying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  There are atheists in foxholes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure there are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I've come to a place in my life where I've come face to face with the facts of life and death. I mean, it's a chance happening I'm alive, it's a miracle, I'm so lucky! And it's not going to last. It's like a shooting star. So beautiful, so fleeting, make a wish before it's gone, you know? I'm so moved.  But cut off.  If there is a God, if there is some kind of music going through everything, I can't hear it.  I'm alone.  I really feel I'm alone. I'm walking down this little path by myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you help me? The Stewardess has returned with their drinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.  I have your drinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah.  Thank you. She serves the priest a little bottle of bourbon and a glass of ice.  He gives her his old glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. Joe is still focussed on Father Conroy.  The good Father carefully pours the little bottle of bourbon over the ice.  Joe is very intense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you help me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. 6/2/89

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you see an analyst of some kind?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't need an analyst. That's not the kind of problem I have. Inspirational light shines through the cabin window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you need a guide.  If you're a seeker and you need a guide, someone to counsel you so you can find your way forward into a spiritual realm.  And you're on an airplane.  Don't look in first class. Father Conroy raises his glass of bourbon in a little toast to Joe, and then takes a healthy swallow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The American flight lands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe and his fellow travellers are just entering the terminal proper.  A commercial airplane presses its nose inquisitively against a visible window.  It is surrounded by orange trees.  Joe is surrounded by blond California guys as he gets off the plane.  We see a homemade banner "Welcome to L.A. St. Dymphna's Girls Academy."  Of the six people waiting, five of them look like Brezhnev.  The sixth is ANGELICA, she is holding aloft a sign which reads "JOSEPH BANKS."  She looks like Dede.  Joe does a take, he goes to her.  Several Catholic school girls run by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, are you Joe Banks?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm the daughter of the guy who hired you.  Angelica Graynamore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. 6/2/89

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Joe shakes her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice to meet you.  Again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? Joe shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daddy told me to tell you that I don't know what he hired you for, and not to tell me.  That I'm totally untrustworthy. I'm a flibberti-gibbet. C'mon, let's get outta here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got some luggage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The taxi is going along a highway.  We LEAVE the taxi and MOVE FORWARD TO a red convertible.  In the red convertible are Angelica at the wheel, and Joe beside her.  They are driving alongside the blue ocean.  Green palm trees wave overhead.  All is beautiful and fresh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've never been to L.A. before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It looks fake.  I like it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The red convertible pulls up to the entrance and we hear Angelica say:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daddy wanted to put you up in Bel Air, but I said no way! Shangri-la, Shangri-la!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. 6/2/89 59        CONTINUED:  (Al) The taxi pulls up behind them.  Angelica gets out of the car and goes back to the cab.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. 5/16/89

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She gives the DRIVER money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.  That's for you.  And put everything on the curb, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. Joe gets out of the convertible.  Two deco-porters emerge from the hotel with luggage carriers, and assist the Driver in transferring the trunks.  Angelica jumps back in her car and calls to Joe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Check in, fresh up, I'll be back for you at seven.  We'll have dinner. Angelica drives off.  Joe looks after, then turns and goes into the hotel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fancy "fun" restaurant.  A big platter of Dungeness crabs being carried through the restaurant.  It's placed on a table where Joe and Angelica are sitting.  There are already two other platters of exotic food on the table. Now we see the waiter and waitress, a slick blond named RALPH and a redheaded waitress named RITA.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Black bread with sour cream and golden caviar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Dungeness crabs. Joe looks at this dish with alarm. Ralph and Rita depart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They do look like little monsters or something. (picks one up and attacks it)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But they're good little monsters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. 6/2/89

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED-
dialogues.text: Joe tentatively takes one, and small portions of the other dishes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd you do before you signed on with Daddy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was an advertising librarian for a medical supply company.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.  I have no response to that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you ask?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, I don't know. Angelica produces and takes two pills.  Suddenly, she gets very defensive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a painter.  And a poet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  Does that bother you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People from New York usually look down on painters.  And poets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't know that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They think if you live in L.A., and you say you're an artist, you really do nothing!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't think I do nothing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. 5/16/89

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You believe me when I say I'm a painter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And a poet.  Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. 1/15/89

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you're right.  There's a painting of mine right there.

dialogues.speaker: 60A PAINTING OF CAR
dialogues.text: in a yellow pool of light overlooking a lit-up city below.  And --

dialogues.speaker: 60B JOE AND ANGELICA
dialogues.text: looking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's terrific.  Where you get your ideas?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll show you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The streetlight casts a pool of light just like in the painting, and the city glitters below.  When Angelica's car pulls into the pool of light and stops, the picture is complete.
