dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice view.  It's like looking down at the stars. Angelica takes two more pills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you want to hear one of my poems?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Long ago, the delicate tangles of his hair, Covered the emptiness of my hands. (to Joe)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you wanna hear it again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Long ago, the delicate tangles of his hair, Covered the emptiness of my hands.                 (CONTINUED) JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. 5/16/89

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She has tears in her eyes.  Joe looks at her, concerned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you ever think about killing yourself?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?  Why would you do that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why shouldn't I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some things take care of themselves.  They're not your job. Maybe they're not even your business.  I like your poem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a grown woman and I live on my father's money.  That restaurant that had my painting up, that's my father's restaurant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you telling me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. (making a joke out of it)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll tell anybody who'll listen. (dropping it)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, that's not true.  I don't know why I'm telling you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen to me.  If you have a choice between killing yourself and doing something you're scared of doing, why not take the leap and do the thing you're scared of doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean stop taking money and leave L.A.?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see?  You know what you're afraid of doing.  Why don't you do it?  See what happens?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. 6/2/89

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Inspired by him, she hesitates on the brink of courage. For a moment she finds it and lifts her hands to say "yes," but her courage fails her. She gets a chill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must be tired. She starts up the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks for listening, but I'm a little high, and you don't know me from Adam, I mean, I guess, Eve.  Anyway, forget it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't mind talking. Suddenly, she's very angry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I do! This is one of those typical conversations where we're all open and sharing our innermost thoughts and it's all bullshit and a lie and it doesn't cost you anything!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look.  I don't know you.  I don't think I know anybody. You're angry.  I can see that. (he quietly gets upset)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm very troubled.  I'm not ready to... There's only so much time and you wanna use it well. So I'm here talking to you, I don't wanna throw that away. You seem...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I seem what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You seem far away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have no response to that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you better take me back to the hotel. His eyes are shining.  She looks at him.  She puts the car in gear and pulls out. JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. 5/16/89

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The red convertible pulls up.  Joe gets out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want me to come in?  I could come up with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright.  Will you have breakfast with me?  I'm supposed to get you to the boat by ten, but I could meet you for breakfast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you I was a flibbertigibbet. She drives off.  Joe turns to go into the hotel, changes his mind, and walks out into the street.  We FOLLOW him. He dodges a lone car, and makes it to the other side where the palm trees grow.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Joe making his way through some greenery.  He parts some tall grass, and we see what he sees -- JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. 6/2/89

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: A couple of stars vaguely twinkle overhead.  There's the DULL BOOM of the SURF.

dialogues.speaker: DOWN WHERE BEACH MEETS OCEAN
dialogues.text: Joe arrives at this spot and sits down in the sand.  He looks out at the ocean, at the horizon, where the night presses down on the water.  Time passes.  The sky gets lighter. MUSIC. The VAGUE beginnings of something MAGICAL and very, very big are heard. A band of golden light hits Joe in the back of the head. He turns around and it's in his eyes.  We see the fake sun rising over a row of palm trees.  Just a touch of red on the horizon. The MAGICAL MUSIC CEASES. But the sun continues to rise.  And rise.  Until it clears the horizon and is a discreet orange-blue disk in the morning sky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun turns into an orange-yellow yolk of a sunnyside- up egg.  The CAMERA PULLS BACK.  Joe and Angelica are eating breakfast.  Joe is dressed like Jungle Jim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm so tired.  You take that stuff, it just ruins your sleep. I'm sorry I was so abusive, immature, hostile, and needy last night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I disappointed you.  So, what did Daddy hire you to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's real complicated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. 6/2/89

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. I don't even know where you're going on the boat. Patricia won't tell me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's Patricia?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's my half-sister. She's the one who's sailing you wherever you're going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daddy loves a secret almost as much as he loves money.  Can I ask you something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you dressed like Jungle Jim?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think this is inappropriate? For the boat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it's fine.  We'd better get going.  I gotta guy dropping your trunks off at the marina who may not have understood my travel directions. They get up to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the end of a long narrow dock is a yacht about 7 feet long.  It dwarfs all the other vessels.  We hear a CAR DOOR SLAM and hear Angelica.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. 5/16/89

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here we are. Now we see Angelica and Joe approach the dock and start walking down it.  We see them FROM the back and hear them talking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's big. They approach the yacht, which is called The Tweedle Dee. It has on its hull a single arrogant eye that looks haughtily at Joe.  On the dock by the yacht are the four steamer trunks.  Sitting on a piling, staring balefully at the trunks is a magnificent, athletic, truly feminine, blonde, blue-eyed woman in her late twenties.  This is PATRICIA.  On The Tweedle Dee two boat boys, MIKE and TONY, ready the yacht for departure; they are young and shining and strong.  Joe and Angelica arrive at the slip. Patricia looks just like Dede and Angelica.  Joe does a take.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Angelica)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You say this is your half- sister?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the trunks, Felix?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're my... My name's not Felix, it's Joe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. (calling out)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike!  Tony!  Find a place for these boxes. Mike and Tony jump off the yacht and proceed to load the trunks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That outfit's wearing you, Felix.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. l/18/89 67        CONTINUED:  (Al)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you calling me Felix? My name's Joe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm calling you Felix because I do what I want.  Hello, Angelica.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. 6/2/89

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Patricia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (simultaneously)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know where Daddy is? PATRICIA (to Joe)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We never know where our father is and we always suspect that the other one knows.  But it's all phone calls and telegrams, hey, Angelica?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you're in a rotten mood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the sunshine.  It gets me down. The boat boys have finished bringing aboard the last trunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you believe it?  Dad said not to tell you.  Goes with my theory. Power makes you paranoid. Mike calls out from the yacht.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All set. Patricia hops off the piling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, get ready to heave, Felix. Joe gets angry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name is Joseph or Joe. Patricia deflates a bit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright.  Joe.  Get ready. We're leaving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. 4/14/89

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Joe turns to Angelica and speaks to her privately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Bye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Bye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen.  Don't take drugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wish me luck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good luck. He takes her hand and gives her a little kiss on the cheek.  She notes his hand.  She's puzzled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're shaking. He smiles, examining his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Am I?  A little. (looks at the land in the distance behind her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. He runs up the gangway.  Patricia has already boarded the boat.  The boat boys are casting off.  Patricia takes the wheel.  But we are still WITH Angelica on the dock.  She stands there.  Slowly, as the yacht pulls away, she waves. Joe stands at the railing, the sails still furled behind him.  He waves back. Now we are WITH Joe on the yacht, at the railing.  He waves a little, and then his eyes rove the shore.

dialogues.speaker: SHORE
dialogues.text: Joe looks at the flag on the stern of The Tweedle Dee. He looks up from the flag at his departing homeland.  A ghost image of the flag follows his glance up so that he sees the following through that image.  He sees Angelica on the dock, and then the boats behind her, and then the parking lot behind that.  And then the hills in the distance off to his left.  And the rich people's houses off to his right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. 8/21/89

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: And cars on roads.  And a smokestack.  He sees all this through the ghost image of that American flag.  He sees his homeland.  Receding.  He's leaving his homeland.  He will never see it again.  And now we see again:

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Staring, moved, determined.  His clothes are a bit much, but he almost fills them in this moment.  A wind comes up and sweeps his safari hat off his head, into the ocean. He flinches slightly at the loss.

dialogues.speaker: HAT
dialogues.text: swirling away into the wake.  But now we see again:

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: And after a glance, he gives up the hat without regret. He continues to look after the receding land.  Without the hat he looks great.  His hair blows in the wind and he stares and stares.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Tweedle Dee has cleared the harbor and the boat boys have started unfurling the sails.  The huge, snowy sails fill with a rich wind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The chef, a German named DAGMAR, is laying out lovely nicoise salads. Tony awaits Dagmar's pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you put out the sunflowers, yet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good! Go. Tony picks up the salads and exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which is shaded by a canopy.  At the table sit Joe and Patricia.  On the table are place settings, white wine, and glasses.  Tony serves their plates and goes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks delicious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. 5/16/89                  58

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We eat well aboard The Tweedle Dee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Tweedle Dee?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the name of this boat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. 6/2/89

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So we're going to the island of Waponi Woo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you ever been there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  All I know about Waponi Woo is that the name means 'the little island with the big volcano,' and that the people, the Waponis, like orange soda.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They like orange soda.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (produces a book called History of Polynesia)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  But here!  I've got a book. 'Eighteen hundred years ago, a Roman galley with a crew of Jews and Druids, got caught in a huge storm off Carthage.  They were swept a thousand miles off course, and ended up on the wrong side of the horn of Africa.  Thinking they were returning to Rome, they sailed deep into the South Pacific, and finally ended by colonizing a lightly populated, Polynesian island which they named Waponi Woo. Thus was born the Waponi culture - a mixture of Polynesian, Celtic, Hebrew and Latin influences.  The Waponis are known throughout Polynesia as having a peculiar love of orange soda and no sense of direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. 3/13/89

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why'd you talk to me so snotty back on the dock?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because you work for my father. And I'm angry with my father.  But he's not around to give him a shot.  So you work for him, I give you a shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why you angry with him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. 1/15/89

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because he's never around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you're angry with him, and he's never around, why are you working for him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't work for him.  My transport of you is strictly a favor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You do favors for people you're mad at?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't work for him!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. 6/2/89

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He said he'd give me this boat if I took you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (defensive)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's got two of them.  This is The Tweedle Dee.  There's a Tweedle Dum, too. She gets up.  She's flustered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got the wheel tied up, which is not good sailing. Excuse me. She goes toward the stern.  Joe is left alone to finish his supper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: is cutting through the blue.  The sun is setting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: is anchored and lit up.  It's a dark and starless night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patricia is showing Joe his berth.  The whole interior of the boat is made of beautiful wood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this okay for you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys like to sleep in the hull.  Dagmar sleeps on deck when the weather's good.  So you've pretty much got things to yourself. I'm in the little stateroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. 3/23/89

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: But Patricia lingers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry I was so rude on the dock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's okay. She finished, but again she lingers, awkward.  Finally, she blurts out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you sleep with my sister?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually, she's my half- sister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I didn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. (again awkward)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you like to fish?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe tomorrow we'll do some fishing. She goes to the entranceway and fingers a switch on the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the light switch.  Did Mike show you how to work the bathroom?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.  Do you want me to turn off the light while I'm going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She turns off the light.  Only the light from the entranceway illuminates her now, and Joe is not visible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love my sister.  I know she's screwed up.  I love my father, even though I never see him and he's not so great when I do see him.  I'm very nervous about this trip.  My father didn't tell me anything and you don't seem to be telling me anything.  But it's more than that.  I've always kept clear of my father's stuff since I got out on my own.  Now he's pulled me back in.  He knew I wanted this boat and he used it and he got me working for him, which I swore I would never do. I feel ashamed because I had a price. He named it.  And now I know that about myself.  I don't know who you are.  I don't know anything about you.  But you're working for him, too, and that makes us two of a kind. I could treat you like I did back on the dock, but that would be me kicking myself for selling out.  Which isn't fair to you and doesn't make me feel any better. I don't know what your situation is.  But I wanted you to know what mine is.  Not just to explain some rude behavior.  But because we're on a little boat for a while and I'm soul sick and you're gonna see that.  Like my sister.  She's soul sick, too.  And if you'd slept with her I would've known something about you.  But you didn't. You didn't.  I believe you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm glad you believe me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you ever slept on a boat before?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. 6/2/89

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It really affects your dreams. I look forward to it.  Even though, sometimes, the dreams really shake me up.  Okay. Good night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night. She departs through the entrance way.  The light goes out, and it's dark and quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a really beautiful sunny day.  Tony is at the wheel, the sails are full and, sitting in two chairs hard by the stern are Joe and Patricia.  They both are holding deep sea fishing rods; they're trolling. MUSIC. "The Girl From Ipanema," the famous recording by Getz and Gilberto, is playing now. Patricia reels in her line.  A beautiful fish is flapping on the end of it.  Joe reels in his line.  Nothing.  He watches as Patricia unhooks her catch and tosses it in a hamper.  Dagmar appears, looks in the hamper, and nods approvingly.  Then she looks at Joe.  Where's Joe's fish? Then he walks away again.  Joe casts again, while Patricia rebates her hook.  Then Patricia casts again. Mike arrives with a beer for Patricia, who accepts it. Mike leaves.  Patricia gets another strike, asks Joe to hold her beer, which he does.  She reels in another beautiful fish.  She unhooks it and throws it in the hamper.  Dagmar appears, looks in the hamper, nods approvingly, and then looks at Joe.  Where's Joe's fish? Joe looks at Dagmar, and then ignores her. Dagmar departs.  Joe goes back to fishing.  Now Joe gets a strike.  It's a big one!  The line goes burning out his reel.  Patricia notices.  She offers to help him.  He waves her off.  Dagmar appears.  She offers some advice. But Joe's completely focused on his rod.  The rod, which is substantial, starts to bend.  Mike comes back to watch.  The rod is almost bent double.  Then it goes madly to the left.  Offers of help are made, but Joe shouts them back.  Then the rod goes madly to the right. Dagmar runs OUT OF VIEW, and reappears with an enormous gaff, which she brandishes excitedly.  A sudden powerful tug almost pulls Joe off the back of the boat, but Mike grabs him just in time.  Joe is a man possessed.  He reels and pulls with superhuman determination.  Without warning, a huge head, the head of a hammerhead shark, appears at the stern.  Its eyes turn inboard and look at Joe.  Everybody drops everything and runs away. JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. 4/14/89

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun has just sunk beneath the horizon's rim so there's still all that sun setting light in the sky.  The first evening star has appeared.  Joe and Patricia are the last left at the dinner's end.  The bones of the fish Patricia caught earlier are on a platter at the table's center. Mike appears and removes the platter and a couple of stray plates, and disappears into the galley.  There are balloon glasses by Joe and Patricia's places and, by Patricia, a bottle of cognac.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you like cognac?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cognac?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I make a point of not knowing about certain things.  One of them's cognac. I like cognac. But I don't want the accepted wisdom about cognac, you know what I mean?  I mean I want glimpses of the myth about it. You see people drink it out of these big glasses, and smelling it forever.  That's interesting to me, that sight of them doing that. But I don't want them to talk to me about it, you know what I mean?  I want to figure it out based on what I've seen from other people, and what I personally get from it. She opens the bottle and pours them both some.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So this is what I've got.  So far. To say about this:  Most cognac is French.  It's very volatile. Like gasoline or model airplane glue.  And when you taste it, in my opinion, it tastes like gasoline or model airplane glue. That's because it's for smelling really.  And I figure that's because the French, physically, tend to have big noses.  They get the pleasure of the cognac through the nose. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. 5/16/89

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You could really just smell it and pour it down the sink. But this isn't French cognac. This is Italian cognac.  It's probably generally considered inferior.  But the news is, it tastes good.  Maybe it doesn't smell as good -- it smells okay - but it tastes good. And when I came to that fork in the road, between the nose and the tongue, I chose the tongue.  So, here's to the tongue. They toast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To the tongue. They drink a little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's good.  Don't the Italians have big noses, too?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  And that really messes up my theory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see it bobbing gently on the sea.  Many stars are coming out, some waxing quite bright.  A half moon, pale and small, hangs in the western sky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe and Patricia have been talking and sipping cognac for an hour and a half.  Patricia is quite mellow, as is Joe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So my understanding, as far as I understand it, is I'm leaving you on this island.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long are you going to stay there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. 5/16/89 81        CONTINUED:  (Al)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For the rest of my life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't imagine that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I couldn't have imagined any of this. He looks at the stars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you used to this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ocean, the stars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You never get used to it.  Why do you think I want this boat? All I want to do is sail away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where would you go

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Away from the things of man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you believe in God?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I believe in myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have confidence in myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've done a lot of soul searching lately.  I've been asking myself some tough questions.  You know what I've found out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have no interest in myself. I think about myself, I get bored out of my mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does interest you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.  Courage. Courage interests me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're going to spend the rest of your life on a tiny island in the South Pacific? She pours them both a drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, up till now I've lived on a tiny island called Staten Island, and I've commuted to a job in a shut up room with pumped in air, no sunshine, despicable people, and now that I've got some distance from that situation, that seems pretty unbelievable. Your life seems unbelievable to me.  All this like life, seems unbelievable to me. Somewhat.  At this moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My father says almost the whole world's asleep. Everybody you know, everybody you see, everybody you talk to.  He says only a few people are awake.  And they live in a state of constant total amazement. They think about that for a while.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have less than six months to live.  The Waponis believe they need a human sacrifice or their island's going to sink into the ocean.  They have a mineral your father wants. He's hired me to jump in their volcano.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. 8/21/89

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not going to make me say that again, are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. A silence falls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aren't you going to say anything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what to say.  You tell me you're dying, you tell me you're jumping into a volcano, my mind is a blank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can understand that

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this disease catching?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. She gets up.  As she leaves she says:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night.  I'll see you in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe enters, undresses to his new underwear, and climbs into the berth.  Then he remembers the light, gets up, turns it off, and climbs back into his berth.  It's dark. We see his face.  He thinks for a moment, and then goes to sleep.  And he has a dream.

dialogues.speaker: 82A DREAM SEQUENCE
dialogues.text: In utter darkness we hear Joe describe his dream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I fell asleep and I had this dream.  I dreamed I was a cowboy in the wilderness.  I dreamed I was a cowboy and I saved this girl...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. 8/21/89

dialogues.speaker: 82A CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Everything goes dead black.  There is the sound of WIND. Then Joe's face suddenly lifts up out of the dream into a CLOSEUP.  Startled, he bangs his head.  He has awakened from his dream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the morning, though you can't see that in here. The boat is rocking Joe around in his berth.  He looks around, bewildered.  He realizes he was dreaming.  Then he realizes the boat is rocking a lot.  He starts to get up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patricia is trying to get the weather on the RADIO, but there's nothing but STATIC.  She puts on a set of headphones and adjusts the dial again; the radio is silent now, only she can hear it.  Joe comes into the galley, his hair still rumpled from sleeping on it

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Little weird today, huh? Patricia waves for him to be quiet.  She listens at the phones another moment, adjusting the dial.  She hears something.  She's glad.  She listens.  Her face darkens. She tears off the phones angrily. Dagmar appears in the hatchway.  She greets Joe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a typhoon warning. Good morning, Mister Banks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks like we're in for a blow. Joe exits. JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. 8/21/89

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ocean which until now has been blue, turns green. Mike is tying up the sails, which have all been taken in. Patricia comes up and starts to assist him.  A wind comes up.  Patricia looks in the direction of the wind.  Joe appears on the forward deck, near Patricia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I help?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  You could tie that up. It feels dead, doesn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  It does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yells)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike, get below!  Start the engine.  Tell Tony to head us into the wind and keep us into the wind!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Mike runs off to do her bidding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There isn't any wind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There will be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you worried? Patricia looks in the direction the wind is coming from.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think we'll be Alright.  The hatches are down, the sails are down, we're ahead of the game.

dialogues.speaker: STORM COMING
dialogues.text: It's dark and it's big.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICIA
dialogues.text: still staring at the storm.  Joe looks where she is looking.  The ENGINE CRANKS UP.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. 8/21/89

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What exactly is a typhoon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, Joe, I think you're going to find out. The shadow of the coming storm comes down the deck from forward and envelopes them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: on the unhappy sea.  The sea has turned very dark, perhaps even black.  The storm breaks with a rising wind, a great BOOM of THUNDER, and a flash of lightning.  It starts to rain, for a moment thinly, and then heavily. White caps appear.  The Tweedle Dee begins to ride up and down the high waves.  Its eye now has a frightened look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the storm.  Mike and Tony wrestle with the wheel to keep the bow into the wind.  They are pummeled by the rain and wind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the storm.  Patricia is trying to send a distress signal on the radio.  Joe watches.  Dagmar is absent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mayday, Mayday, Mayday, latitude 10 degrees, 8 minutes south, longitude approximately 150 degrees, 18 minutes west. We are in severe distress. Mayday, Mayday, latitude 10 degrees, 8 minutes south, longitude approximately 150 degrees, 18 minutes west.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What should I do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't go on deck!  Check on Dagmar.  She went forward to look at the engine. JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. 8/21/89

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the storm.  Dagmar has just finished lifting the floorboards and she's checking the gauges on the engine with a flashlight.  Joe approaches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks good, but I'm going to stay with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Joe departs.  A little water drips down on Dagmar.  She looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the storm.  A huge wave engulfs Mike and Tony.  They disappear within the wall of the water, and then re appear, still hanging onto the wheel.  This happens a second time.  They withstand the onslaught.  Then Mike sees something forward and points it out to Tony.  He leaves Tony at the wheel and starts to crawl forward. Lightning flashes nearby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the storm.  Patricia is still trying to get through on the radio. Joe looks out the cabin window and sees a fish swimming. He is uneasy, but says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mayday, Mayday!  Latitude 10 degrees, 8 minutes south, longitude approximately 150 degrees, 18 minutes west. Severe distress!  Severe distress! She drops the mike as Joe enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No way is anybody getting this. How's Dagmar?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. 8/21/89                  74

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. The hatch bursts open, Mike falls in amidst water and the ROAR of the STORM.  He and Joe struggle and close the hatch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The main boom doesn't look secure!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it's gonna bust loose. Without another word, Mike goes back out the hatch again. Joe shuts it behind him.  Patricia rips open a cabinet, and pulls out a coil of nylon rope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's my boat. She goes out the hatch.  Joe follows her. JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. 6/2/89

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In severe distress in the storm.  Patricia and Joe crawl along the deck, battered by the raging typhoon. Patricia looks up.

dialogues.speaker: MAIN BOOM
dialogues.text: There's too much play in it.  It's swinging from side to side.  If it swings much longer, it's going to snap its stays.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICIA AND JOE
dialogues.text: continue to crawl toward it.  Patricia clutching the coil of rope.  Lightning flashes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the storm.  Mike and Tony wrestling with the wheel and being inundated with water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the storm.  A little steady stream of water is splashing on Dagmar, which she ignores.  She's adjusting the timing of the engine with a fat screwdriver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the storm.  With Joe's help, she starts to secure the boom, but a sudden roll of the boat throws them back, pinning them against a cabin wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe and Patricia pinned against the wall.  The rain pouring over their faces.  They are close, looking at each other, panting, illuminated by lightning.  They lunge toward each other, careless of danger, and passionately kiss.  The kiss ends.  They look at each other.  The boat rolls the other way, breaking the spell. They are thrown toward the boom again.

dialogues.speaker: BOOM
dialogues.text: At this moment, the boom breaks free.  Joe has fallen to the deck, while Patricia is still standing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. 3/23/89

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The boom swings over Joe and slams into Patricia, knocking her unconscious and into the raging sea.  Joe stands up and, still holding the coil of rope, dives into the ocean after her.  A SLOW-MO stylized leap.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: in the raging sea looking for Patricia in the storm.  He dives under the water once, twice, but he doesn't find her.  He looks around desperate.  He sees something.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICIA'S HAND
dialogues.text: disappearing under the waves.  Illuminated in a single flash of lightning.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Swims and dives.  He pulls her up, so her head's above the surface of the water.  She's unconscious and battered.  A flash of lightning catches Joe's attention. He looks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lightning forks around the ship once, twice, and then the third time it strikes.  A massive bolt that sunders the yacht.  It's the same German expressionist's bolt as at the beginning of the story:  ACHI's logo.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Joe's stunned face illuminated by the great flash.  He is holding the unconscious Patricia.

dialogues.speaker: THE TWEEDLE DEE
dialogues.text: sinking, in the storm.  The Tweedle Dee's eyes have turned to Xs.  The yacht swamps and disappears beneath the swirling waves.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: getting tired, holds Patricia's head above water.  He accidentally swallows a gulletful of seawater, chokes, splutters, and recovers himself.  But he's panting.  How long can he hold on?  But then he sees something! JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. 3/23/89

dialogues.speaker: STEAMER TRUNK
dialogues.text: One of the steamer trunks bobbing.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: towing Patricia, starts swimming for the trunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe reaches the trunk.  He grabs on to it gratefully, recovers his breath, and then hoists Patricia as high up on it as he can.  He takes the nylon rope and lashes her to the trunk.  Then he gets a good grip on the trunk himself, and braces against the storm.

dialogues.speaker: JOE AND PATRICIA
dialogues.text: Joe and Patricia on the trunk.  Patricia is still unconscious and Joe is asleep, exhausted.  The storm is over, and the sky is overcast.  Joe blinks and wakes up. He tries to wake Patricia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patricia?  Patricia? But she's out cold.  He looks around.  He sees something.

dialogues.speaker: OTHER THREE STEAMER TRUNKS
dialogues.text: The sun shines through a crack in the clouds and lands, sparkling, on the three other trunks which are floating in the same area.  They are all that survived the sinking.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: lights up upon seeing his trunks.  He tentatively moves a little away from Patricia on her trunk and, satisfied that she's not going to go under, he swims off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe arriving at one of the other trunks, grabs it by the handle and starts towing it back towards Patricia's trunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe arriving at Patricia's trunk with the second.  He lets it go and swims back for another. JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. 4/14/89

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe towing the fourth trunk into proximity with the others.  He takes out his Swiss Army knife and cuts some rope from Patricia's truss.  He uses it to tie two of the trunks together.

dialogues.speaker: TWENTY MINUTES LATER
dialogues.text: Joe with three trunks tied together.  He is easing Patricia's unconscious form on to the three ganged- together trunks.  Having accomplished this, he slides the fourth trunk into position with the other three and begins to secure it with the remaining rope.  The four trunks together make up a raft of ten feet square.  Joe crawls onto the raft, totally exhausted, reaches out a hand to the still form of Patricia, and passes out.  The fog begins to thin.  A few shafts of sunlight dapple the raft.

dialogues.speaker: SUN
dialogues.text: The sun sets into the South Pacific and night begins to fall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Under the stars, Joe and Patricia, he asleep and she unconscious, lie unknowing under an enormous canopy of stars.  The universe is great and they are small.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The little raft in bright, fresh sunlight.  Joe stirs and wakes.  He tries to wake Patricia, but to no avail.  He looks in all directions.  Nothing but blue horizon. After a moment's thought, he opens one of the trunks. But it's the wrong one.  He secures it and opens another. He takes out a violin case and opens it; it's a bar masquerading as a violin case, the one he bought at Hammacher Schlemmer.  It contains two bottles of Moet champagne, two champagne glasses and two bottles of Pellegrino water.  Joe takes out one of the bottles of water and closes the case.  Then he gets his little world-band radio out of the trunk and sets it down.  He opens the Pellegrino water and starts to drink.  But then he thinks.  He looks at Patricia.  Her lips are a little parched.  He looks up at the sun.

dialogues.speaker: SUN
dialogues.text: The sun looks kind of powerful. JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. 5/16/89

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: looks again at the bottle of water.  He decides not to drink any.  He pours a little into the bottle cap, and presses the cap to Patricia's lips.  He repeats the process and then, satisfied, screws the cap on the bottle again and puts it away in the case.  Then he puts the case back in the trunk and fastens the lid.  He turns ON the RADIO.  STATIC.  Turns the dial.  The VOICE of a GERMAN ANNOUNCER speaks confidentially.  Joe turns the dial.  A JAPANESE ANNOUNCER's VOICE solemnly intones a short statement in Japanese ending with "Elton John." Joe immediately switches the station.  The song "Goodbye Cruel World" begins to play.  Joe sits listening for what seems a long time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe is discovered with his ukulele, looking at the sky. He is staring at the millions of stars overhead.  He is full of wonder.  He is singing.  He is singing "The Cowboy Song."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ee he o he-o cowboy Ee he o he-o oooo Ee he o he-o cowboy, cowboy, cowboy Under the moon I was riding my horse By the Rio Grand-ee And all the coyotes singin' In a prairie symphony I was ridin' my horse Down by the Rio Grand-ee When I seen me a cowboy, cowboy, cowboy Ridin' towards me Ee he o he-o cowboy Ee he o he-o oooo Ee he o he-o cowboy, cowboy, cowboy Under the moon He was twirling his guns And he had a guitar And we sang us up a sweet old song about love Under the stars (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. 5/16/89

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ee he o he-o cowboy Ee he o he-o oooo Ee he o he-o cowboy, cowboy, cowboy Under the moon Giddyup

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe is chipping golf balls on his Hammacher Schlemmer practice green.  Occasionally making a shot, occasionally hitting one into the water.  One of the golf balls gets tossed back onto the raft.  Joe looks.  There is a mischievous DOLPHIN who LAUGHS and then submerges.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: 127B JOE SITTING ON RAFT
dialogues.text: Joe is listening to the radio.  A Hawaiian disk jockey comes on.  His name is PETE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is K.R.U., Honolulu, speakin' ta ya from the shadow of the Koolau Mountains.  And here's one that was a hit when I was a kid. Sukiyaki. The song "Sukiyaki," which became a pop hit in America, even though it's sung in Japanese, begins to play.  Joe is satisfied and lies back to listen. JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. 4/14/89

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Radio is off.  Joe is trying out his aquatic shoes.  Just trying his first tentative steps, he accidentally punctures one of his shoes so it deflates.  He topples over to one side.  He swims back to the raft, abandoning his shoes.  He turns the RADIO ON, but it's only giving out a little STATIC now.  He checks on Patricia, but gets no response.  He tries to get something on the radio, but the batteries are too weak now.  He turns it OFF.  He notices he's sweating.  He shifts, knocking the radio in the ocean.  Irritated, he looks up.

dialogues.speaker: SUN
dialogues.text: The sun looms down, hot and white and huge.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: looks at the sun with concern.  He gets out the violin case.  He gets the water out and fills the cap and ministers to Patricia.  His lips are parched, but he takes none for himself.  He takes off his now well- seasoned safari jacket and puts it over Patricia, to protect her from the sun.  We hear a sound, like the HISS of something being SEARED in a SKILLET.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again, the sky is ablaze with stars.  They're even brighter than previously.  Joe is looking at them.  He's shaking.  He's got a fever.  He closes his eyes and then opens them again.  He looks at the stars again.  And shakes his head in disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: STARS
dialogues.text: What's this?  the stars are all connected together with little pale blue lines, and over that are boldly visible the astrological signs:  The Flying Horse, The Archer, The Twins, etc.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: shakes his head, bewildered and amazed.  He blinks and looks again.

dialogues.speaker: STARRY NIGHT
dialogues.text: All of the lines and pictures are gone.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: looks and looks.  But no, they are gone.  It's just a starry night.  He relaxes, closes his eyes, and quakes with fever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe, very ill with fever, checks the water supply. There's a little less than half a bottle of water left. His lips are deeply cracked.  But still he takes no water for himself.  He looks up at the sun.  The sound of SIZZLING. JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. 4/14/89

dialogues.speaker: SUN
dialogues.text: The sun burns down, bright and big.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: pours a capful of water and gives it to Patricia.  She is still unconscious, but she looks pretty good.  It's Joe that's really going down the tubes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We come in on Joe's face.  Joe quakes with fever.  Then he sees something.  Joe is entranced by what he sees.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT SKY
dialogues.text: The astrological signs have appeared in the sky again as they did the night before.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: stares.  He's half mad with fever.  What is he seeing?

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT SKY
dialogues.text: The dome of astrological signs begins to rotate from horizon to horizon so that the full panoply of the ancient mythology is revealed.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: is frightened, moved.  His eyes fill with tears.

dialogues.speaker: 144C SKY
dialogues.text: The sky has returned to its ordinary self. JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. 6/2/89

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: wonders if he really saw the astrological signs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another scorching day under the sun.  Joe looks very bad. He's got a fever.  He's slowly dying of thirst.  He gets out the bottle, gives a capful to the still unconscious Patricia, and then looks at the water level.  There's a quarter of a bottle left.  He puts the bottle away.  He crawls to the raft's edge and plunges his head in the sea.  A dolphin sticks his head out of the water and looks at Joe.  Joe lifts his head out of the water and finds himself looking at a dolphin who is looking at him. Man and fish are just a few feet apart.  They regard each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello.  My name is Joe. The DOLPHIN makes SOUNDS.  It could be talking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm dying.  Ahead of schedule. The Dolphin disappears back beneath the water.  Joe lowers his head and lies still.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again, it is a great starry night.  Joe, weak and sick and bleary-eyed, looks up at the stars.  He closes his eyes.  He opens them again.  Again, he is astonished.

dialogues.speaker: HEAVENS
dialogues.text: All the lines and astrological signs are back, brilliant and splendid.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: rouses himself, crawling to his knees to look.  He stares in utter wonder. The signs begin to rotate again. MUSIC. Earlier, in L.A. Joe stared at the horizon, just before dawn, and big, magical music began to play.  But then it stopped prematurely.  That MUSIC begins to play now, but this time it does not stop.  It's the big, dramatic pas de deux music from "The Nutcracker."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. 4/14/89

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The astrological signs melt away into Disney dust as a light appears at the horizon.

dialogues.speaker: HORIZON
dialogues.text: A light appears at the horizon's edge.

dialogues.speaker: 149B ENORMOUS MOON
dialogues.text: with slow majesty rises from the glittering sea, directly to Joe's front. Joe and his little raft are utterly dwarfed by this great heavenly body.

dialogues.speaker: 149C JOE ON HIS RAFT
dialogues.text: Though he is on the verge of utter collapse he is so moved by what he sees he clambers his way to his shaky feet and raises his arms over his head in complete reverence.  He is dwarfed.  He's a bug.  The raft is a mote in the eye of God.  Joe is deeply moved, humbled, awestruck.  The moon continues to ascend up and up and out of view.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED
dialogues.text: thru

dialogues.speaker: 151A
dialogues.text: 15lB   JOE looks at the stars that are simply stars.  Sinking to his knees, he presses his hands to his breast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dear God, whose name I do not know, thank you for my life. I forgot how big... Thank you for my life Joe slowly crumbles, physically crumbles from thirst and fever and exhaustion.  His eyes dim. JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. 3/23/89

dialogues.speaker: STARS
dialogues.text: We watch the stars DISSOLVE, and BLACKNESS closes in. Then the blackness starts to FADE, become rosy.  We hear the sound of LABORED BREATHING.  WATER being POURED. Someone COUGHING a little, CHOKING a little, and then recovering.  Then we hear Patricia's voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe?  Joe?  Didn't you drink any water for yourself?  Joe?

dialogues.speaker: LIGHT FOG
dialogues.text: begins to clear. And there, above him, ministering to him, is Patricia.  She has the bottle at his lips giving him a little to drink at a time.

dialogues.speaker: JOE'S HEAD
dialogues.text: is cradled in Patricia's arm. She has the bottle at his lips.  He pushes it away, croaking weakly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long have I been unconscious?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.  Days.  You woke up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess I did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. She gives some more water over his weak resistance.  The bottle has one more sip in it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finish this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  You need it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel pretty good.  You look like shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's good to hear you talking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. 2/16/89

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, drink it.  Don't you wanna be in good shape for the Waponis?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll never make it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talking about? Look. She points.  Joe looks where she points.

dialogues.speaker: D
dialogues.text: One island is small and barren.  The other island sports a big volcano.  A little steady stream of smoke issues from the volcano's mouth.  We hear Patricia's voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a miracle.  We must've lucked into the right tidal current.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICIA
dialogues.text: looks at Joe.  She makes him take the last sip of water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened to the yacht?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Struck by lightning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No sign of Dagmar or the boys?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything went under.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Except your trunks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Except my trunks. He takes a look at the island.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So that's Waponi Woo.

dialogues.speaker: ISLAND
dialogues.text: JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. 4/14/89

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We FLY OVER the surface of the ocean TO the island.  TO:

dialogues.speaker: ONE HILL ON ISLAND
dialogues.text: on which stands a lookout.  The lookout's name is EMO. Emo is scanning the sea with an old telescope on a stand. In his free hand, he holds a can of orange soda called Jump.  He sips from this with great relish.  Then he spots something with the telescope.  It's the raft!  He carefully puts down his soda, cups his hands, and lets out with a mighty formal cry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah bey! We now hear fifty voices answer from all over the island.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ho!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah bey!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ho!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kimo Sabby Sah!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ha-ha-ha-ha-ha-ha!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe and Patricia hear the cries and look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think we've been spotted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outrigger canoes lay along the shore.  The EXCITED CRIES of running NATIVES are heard approaching.  And now we see them.  It's the Waponis!  They are a motley lot, used to the good life.  They sport big orange dots on their fore heads.  They carry fruit, garlands of flowers, and cans of Jump.  They leap into their canoes and head out toward the raft.  Their eyes are enhanced with liner. JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. 3/23/89

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as the canoes reach it.  The leader of the welcoming group, BAW, calls out to Joe in a formal way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whooa!  Are you Joe?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. 4/14/89

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (impressed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whooa!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you Joe Banks?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to group)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pelica beeble bum bum! The welcoming group goes crazy, showering the little raft with a thousand flowers.  Joe and Patricia exchange a look through the shower of flowers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess they're glad to see us. They're both handed cans of Jump.  Natives grab the pop tops with their teeth and rip them off, smiling.  Joe and Patricia drink from the cans of Jump.  All the natives cheer.  Then hands reach out and pull them gently off their raft and into the canoes.  Another canoe's occupants get a grass rope and tie it to the raft.  Now we see:

dialogues.speaker: WHOLE FLOTILLA OF CANOES
dialogues.text: Joe and Patricia, and the whole welcoming group, covered with flowers and drinking Jump, head for the island. With the raft of trunks in tow.  The welcoming group, led by Baw, sing a Polynesian "Song of Happiness."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as the canoes arrive.  Upon reaching the shore, Joe and Patricia are hoisted onto the shoulders of the natives and carried inland.  Then we see other natives hoisting the trunks onto their shoulders and following. Everybody's singing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two guys hoisting an enormous spool of homemade red carpet on a wooden yoke lead the way into the jungle providing the "Red Carpet Treatment." JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. 4/14/89

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The red carpet unrollers run through a stretch of Jungle. Through a thin veil of greenery we see unrollers pass by us on a jungle path.  After a second they are followed by Joe and Patricia and the full happy entourage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exhausted, our carpet men, their spindle all but spent, stumble into the village's center.  Their carpet reaches its tail.  They drop to the ground, gasping and proud. The welcoming group arrives with Patricia and Joe and the whole village turns out and goes nuts.  Some of them carry ducks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. 4/14/89

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Then from the biggest hut emerges the CHIEF.  Instantly, everything stops and all the natives are lying face down on the ground, utterly silent.  Only Joe and Patricia are left standing to face the Chief.  The Chief is a big, impressive man with grey hair and in totally traditional native costume.  Most of the other natives have some element of Western dress about their person.  The Chief has a sad, rich voice, a voice full of memory and knowledge.  He holds a tiki teddy bear.  It has atrophied little arms and legs; its hair is standing on end.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is that?  A teddy bear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  It is my soul.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope you don't lose it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So do I.  I am Tobi.  Chief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Patricia Graynamore. I'm Joe Banks.  You speak English.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have learned.  You have come to stop the anger of the Woo? The Chief points upward.  Joe looks where he points.

dialogues.speaker: VOLCANO, (BIG WOO)
dialogues.text: Smoke issues from the mouth of the Big Woo steadily.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: looks away from the volcano.  He looks into the eyes of the chief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There was worry that you would not come.  You were to come before this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well.  I'm here now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. 4/14/89

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The Chief nods sadly.  He looks at Patricia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're with him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. The Chief nods sadly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: l67    CONTINUED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tonight, we will have a big feast. And then, at the end of the feast, we will climb to the top of the Big Woo, and you will jump in. Okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The women will take this woman and make her clean for the feast. (shouts to the native women)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pelica!  Pelica! The native women rise quickly to their feet, giggling and excited, and make off with Patricia.  She calls out as she's taken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patricia!  Is she gonna be Alright? The Chief nods wearily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the men will take you and make you right for the feast. (shouts to the native men)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oliva!  Oliva! The native men leap up with a shout, seize Joe, and carry him off.  Other native men follow, carrying the trunks. The Chief, weary, heads back inside his hut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: which has been set up to clean Joe.  What can only be described as a giant bassinet made out of beautiful, soft greenery has been set up in the clearing, along with many coconut bowls.  Into this a violently protesting Joe, stark naked, is being pressed by the laughing native men. They dump many bowls of water over him while he desperately tries to hide his genitals, first with his hands, and then by turning face down in the bassinet. Then the men take mounds of fresh fruit that has been cut up and rub it into Joe's flesh.  Then six of the native men produce big shining fish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. 4/14/89

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: They hold these fish by the tails.  Other men hold Joe still.  Then the men rhythmically beat Joe with the fish. They hum to keep time.  They are giving him a massage. At first he reacts by screaming, but then he starts to groan, as one does from an important massage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of the natives holds forward a tray covered with a thin blue material.  Joe looks at it with interest.  The native gently, physically closes Joe's eyes, then blows the contents of the tray, a thin, bright blue powder directly into Joe's face.  Joe opens his eyes, a wiser man.  They lick the powder off his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are dousing Joe with water again, only he's sitting up now, eating a piece of fruit.  Emo, the lookout, offers him a Jump, but Joe shakes his head.  Emo looks amazed and comments to the others in a low voice, in another language.  Their reply to Emo's comment is a low Whoa!; they are incredulous.  Then they go back to dousing Joe.  He likes this treatment by now.  Then a look of concern passes over his face and he looks down.

dialogues.speaker: JOE'S BARE FEET
dialogues.text: Two natives are chewing the toenails on his two feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, stop that! The two natives look at him blankly, and go back to what they're doing.  Joe accepts it.  Another native is massaging his scalp, adding a little oil to Joe's hair. The native combs the hair with his fingers.  Joe's starting to look like his old self.  Something on the edge of the clearing catches his eye.

dialogues.speaker: FOUR STEAMER TRUNKS
dialogues.text: A little stained with salt, but otherwise none the worse for wear. JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. 4/14/89

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: looking at the trunks, gets an idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patricia is near the end of a make-over by the native women.  They are adorning her freshly-washed hair with beautiful flowers, and wrapping her sparkling body in a pretty sarong. JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. 8/25/89

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SUN
dialogues.text: sets behind the Big Woo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Going full blast in the village.  MUSIC.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fire plays on Patricia's face, as she's escorted by four village women into the village feast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Handheld, as she walks through the village.

dialogues.speaker: 176A ON PATRICIA, (INTERCUT)
dialogues.text: As she's led through village.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's my friend?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's Joe Banks? a.  Men dancing on dusty drums. b.  Natives criss-cross jumping over fire, with the band in the b.g. c.  A pig on a spit over a fire.

dialogues.speaker: 177A ON PATRICIA, (INTERCUT)
dialogues.text: As she's led through the village.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is my friend here?

dialogues.speaker: HANDHELD
dialogues.text: a.  Fire-eaters on either side of a small volcano. The MUSIC changes to a new cue: the drum vamp. b.  The Fire-God emerges from the small volcano. JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. 8/25/89

dialogues.speaker: PATRICIA
dialogues.text: She reacts and looks at:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baw comes into the playing area, a half-moon circle of natives.  He clicks the sticks of his fingers.  He looks side-to-side, sternly, with his hands on his hips and cries out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oliva! This is the cue for the story-telling MUSIC to begin. Baw does a little Waponi dance in a tight circle, as he recites.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A whila way Waponi Woo I sangda wangda offda blue I sangda wangda and I aw saw The whorl in all a raw dindour! Meckalecka? Yapa Yapaya Yapa Yapaya Yapa Yapaya Sup up vulca The women scream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terra not firma. To take to Tobi, put the pants! The men cheer and Baw picks up the Tiki doll to hand it to the Volcano God who then goes back into the volcano.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patricia is standing.  Everyone else is BELOW FRAME and there is dead silence.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF
dialogues.text: He's decked out, and he sits in his chair.  His Tobi is in another and there are empty chairs on each side. JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. 8/25/89

dialogues.speaker: 182A PATRICIA
dialogues.text: is gestured to sit in the chair on the Chief's left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look good, now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe Banks said your name is Graynamore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've had talks with Samuel Harvey Graynamore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's my father. The Chief nods sadly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your father is like the Big Woo. He must be fed or he will destroy the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know where my friend, Joe Banks, is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe he ran away?  Maybe he don't want to jump in the Big Woo. Maybe he's swimming to someplace else.  Maybe he swam to that no good island over there. The Chief now calls to the natives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oliva! Oliva! Bum bum bum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two natives swing on grass ropes, from the TOP of the FRAME.  They pass each other on their way to the gongs which hang at either end of the frame.  They slam into the gongs and then fall into two little broken piles. JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev . 8/25/89

dialogues.speaker: 183A THE CHIEF
dialogues.text: He reacts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back to the gong scene (but under cranked) as the stretcher bearers carry the men away and big drums are upended and rolled away in the wake of the stretchers - off to the right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The natives all rise and face Woo and sing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wo-o-o-o-o.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It erupts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Woo wants his flesh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Natives react and scream and the screams turn to cheers, as we --

dialogues.speaker: JOE BANKS
dialogues.text: He appears at the top of a grand staircase.  He descends (as the MUSIC resumes). The crowd faces him and cheers, as they turn with him as he walks across to the Chief and stands before him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So.  You didn't run away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I made a deal and I'll stick by it. The Chief nods sadly.  Joe sits down in the third chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you like my tux?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. 8/25/89

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pretty great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought I might as well go out in style.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're really going to do it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Joe and Patricia have been talking across the Chief,  who sits between them.  Now a groaning native, holding his jaw, comes forward and, after prostrating himself, speaks excitedly to the Chief, addressing him as Tobi, and continuing in another language.  The Chief listens and then waves him away.  The groaning native departs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong with that man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His teeth have holes in them from drinking orange soda. Jump. The Chief hates Jump.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did he want you to do about it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are those who want a man who will fix the holes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dentist

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. The Chief hates this idea.  The VOLCANO THUNDERS again. This time it shakes the ground a little.  They look.

dialogues.speaker: BIG WOO
dialogues.text: The volcano lets out with two tongues of flame this time, and a shower of sparks. JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. 8/25/89

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF AND COMPANY
dialogues.text: looking at volcano.  The Chief then looks at Joe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe Banks.  We are the children of children and we live as we are shown.  Now a change has come. The Waponis like this soda, and no one among my people will jump into the Big Woo.  They trade with this man, your father, for a hero.  We have no hero-of our own.  So we give this man the right to dig holes in the ground under us like the Jump digs holes in our teeth and in some short time we will be nothing but holes.  I am the Tobi. I cannot be the hero. It is my place to hope for my people.  But the Woo calls and no one from among my people says, I will go to my end for the rest of you.  Joe Banks. We are not your people.  Let us die. Take a boat and your woman and go to that no good island over there. (jerks his thumb)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't jump in the Big Woo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have no people of my own, Chief. I'm my only hope for a hero. The BIG WOO THUNDERS AGAIN -  they all look. The feast grows quiet and somber.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Once more I'll call among the Waponis for a hero. The Chief stands.  The Waponis abase themselves.  The Chief speaks to them solemnly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who knew woe sue-weigh? Who knew woe? (he waits; as no one moves; he calls out once more)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drama said, said sue-weigh? (he waits; as no one moves; he is disgusted with them; he speaks with finality and dismissal)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I na box, bum, pelica.  Box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. 8/25/89

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The Waponis slowly get up, shamefaced.  The Chief sits. He speaks to Joe and Patricia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are all afraid to die. There is no hero among them. They deserve to die. Joe stands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take me to the volcano. Natives cheer.  They form an aisle again, leading off in the direction of the Big Woo.  Flaming torches dot the aisle.  The natives start the same call and response they had going when Joe's raft was first sighted.  Emo calls and the natives respond.  This call and response continues through all the following.  Joe walks off, down the aisle.  The Chief follows him.  Before Patricia can follow the Chief, the crowd closes in, following Joe up the mountain.  Patricia tries to reach Joe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe!  Joe! But she can't be heard above the din of the call and response.  She's restrained by the women in the village.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A head torch man leads the way up the mountain path.  He carries a heavy, lit torch that he swings from side to side with a ritual motion.  With each swing he lights another permanent tiki sconce along the path's upward progress.  He is followed by Joe, dapper and alone.  Joe in turn is followed by the Chief, who walks with a ritual movement, not unlike the bent-kneed gait of a Sumo wrestler, leaning first on one leg then on the other.  He is assisted in this gyration by two lackeys, one to his left, one to his right, who catch him as he leans to his most extreme angle and gently shoves him back the other way.  Behind the Chief, comes the general native population all of whom carry torches.

dialogues.speaker: 186D WHOLE VILLAGE
dialogues.text: is going up the trail, with Joe and the Chief at the head of the column.  Some of the natives carry ducks. JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. 8/25/89                  98

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flaming torches now delineate the trail up the mountain. The line they describe looks very like a German expressionist version of a lightning bolt.  The Big Woo is RUMBLING more and more.  The whole sky over the mountain is suffused with red.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patricia struggles.  She's slowly struggling up the length of the column. JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev. 6/2/89

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She's starting to get hysterical.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe!  Joe!  Don't do it! Don't do it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are silent and solemn and focussed.  They arrive at a spot just below the rim of the volcano.  There is a little well worn trail leading from they stand to where the rim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there any ceremony or anything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  You just jump in. Joe nods.  Patricia breaks through the crowd and throws herself at Joe's feet.  She's sobbing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't do it!  Please don't do it, Joe!  I love you!  I've fallen in love with you!  I've never loved anybody!  I don't know how it happened!  And I've never even slept with you or anything and now you're going to kill yourself! Joe pulls her to her feet.  The Chief takes a step away, to give them privacy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You love me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I love you!  I can feel my heart!  I feel like I'm going crazy!  You can't die and leave me here on this stinking earth without you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got to do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?  The Chief doesn't even want you to do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOE VERSUS THE VOLCANO - Rev . 6 / 2 / 8 9

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Cause I've wasted my whole life.  And now I'm going to die.  I've got a chance to die like a man and I'm going to take it!  I've got to take it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you, too.  I've never loved anybody, either.  It's great. I'm glad.  But the timing stinks. Joe kisses her, waves to the Chief, and starts to walk up the little path.  The natives are silent, staring.  The Chief is sad.  Patricia is rooted, staring after him, stricken.  When Joe has just about reached the summit, Patricia wakes from her trance, and bolts up the little path after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Throughout the following, occasionally we CUT TO a carved wooden figure of an alarmed but committed little man, who is under the platform holding it up.  Of course, he's actually an inanimate strut, but as his little knees quake ever more violently under the platform's oppressive weight, we fear for the moment when he and therefore the platform on which Joe and Patricia stand will give way and fall into the volcano.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE SHELF ON MOUTH OF WOO
dialogues.text: Behind them are flames and sparks and smoke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get out of here!  Go back down!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please let me do what I've got to do!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
